rename.from: ValueError: error parsing asn1 value: ParseError when loading Cert with Unicode Chars
rename.to: ValueError: error parsing asn1 value: ParseError when handling Cert with Unicode Chars

body:
This is occurring because the value for the OID 2.5.4.8 (stateOrProvinceName) doesn't contain valid unicode at all. `\xf4` is not a valid unicode character. Based on context it looks like there's an expectation that this encodes Ã´, but that is encoded as `\x00\xf4` in utf16 and `\xc3\xb4` in utf8. Our API requires that values by representable as python strings and so our parser decodes assuming utf8 (except in specific cases where we know that the underlying ASN.1 string type guarantees utf16 or utf32).

This certificate is definitely invalid (and the reason you're seeing it fail in your example is because our `__repr__` parses subject/issuer which immediately triggers the exception), but we'd like to know a bit more about where you're seeing these and what's generating this type of invalid encoding if you can share.

Not my certificate, @danaelg reported the issue to me since this certificate breaks authentik which uses cryptography (see https://github.com/goauthentik/authentik/issues/2082), maybe they can give some light on what they used to generate the certificate.

Very interresting !
It was generated using pfsense cert manager (v2.5.2).

Notably \xF4 is how you'd encode this character in latin-1. It sounds like pfsense is not handling unicode correctly. I don't actually have a pfsense myself, if someone here does have one it'd be good if we could definitely prove this and file a bug with them.

As for now I'm the only one concerned by this bug, I'll open an issue in pfsense bug tracker. I'll give them the information you all provided in this issue.

Thanks.
Please share a link when you do file it!

I create a post on reddit /r/PFSENSE before creating an issue in their bug tracker (this is what they recommand) and a user sent me the link to an already opened issue that I had not found: https://redmine.pfsense.org/issues/12035.

This issue will be resolve in the next release coming early 2022.

reddit post : https://www.reddit.com/r/PFSENSE/comments/s1mn2g/cert_manager_doesnt_handle_utf8/

I've tested the beta of the next release. I can confirm it's resolved. they actually prevent the use of UTF-8 char (that's a way of doing...).

I think we can close this issue.

Thanks again for your light !
I'm actually going to hold this open: I'd like us to improve the error message that one gets here to include which field is invalid so folks have an easier time debugging.

> I'm actually going to hold this open: I'd like us to improve the error message that one gets here to include which field is invalid so folks have an easier time debugging.

I'm trying to debug a similar issue. The error message I now get is the following:

```
 ParseError { kind: InvalidValue, location: ["0", "AccessDescription::access_method"] }
```

Not sure which field it could refer to. Any thoughts on what could cause an error like this?

AccessDescription is within a SubjectInformationAccess or (much more likely) AuthorityInformationAccess extension (typically used for OCSP URIs). The access_method is an ObjectIdentifier defining the type of access method encoded. This suggests you appear to have a cert with an invalid OID encoded. Is this something you can share?

Here's the section containing the OID. I can send you the entire file via email if that helps.

```
        X509v3 extensions:
            X509v3 Basic Constraints: critical
                CA:FALSE
            X509v3 Subject Key Identifier:
                31:C5:62:B6:EE:0F:2C:80:C3:E1:C5:69:ED:BD:2D:F2:48:A4:60:10
            X509v3 Subject Alternative Name:
                URI:urn:publicid:IDN+emulab.net+user+cskama, email:cskama@emulab.net, URI:urn:uuid:d9ed7775-7318-11eb-b1eb-e4434b2381fc
            Authority Information Access:
                2.25.305821105408246119474742976030998643995 - URI:https://www.emulab.net:12369/protogeni/xmlrpc/sa
```

Sorry for commenting on this somewhat unrelated issue.

I noticed that the OID above contains a rather large integer. Looking at the `asn1` crate it seems like it does not support anything greater than 32bits.
(See here: https://github.com/alex/rust-asn1/blob/68695c805ee44c33c91bb1169b613c34a7ad6d60/src/object_identifier.rs#L59)

Is the OID in my certificate even valid? If so, `asn1` probably needs to be patched to support larger numbers in OIDs.
